Sagan asks more questions than he gives answers so it turned out to be a great exercise for my brain (maybe that's what my brain wanted all along!) If you want to think critically and expand your horizons a bit, give this gem a shot!

I think that this book may have been interesting when he wrote it, but the vast majority of Sagan's "speculations on the evolution of human intelligence" have either been scientifically evaluated or are not really testable. Most of the interest of reading the book now is in the fun of seeing how people were thinking about things at the time the book was written. We've definitely come a long way! For instance, at the time the book was written, little was known about the function of sleep, how brains work, and the neuroscience behind many brain diseases. Sagan's speculations feel like a snapshot of a history of science class. Here was the time in history when Lashley's equipotentiality hypothesis of the brain was losing support, when Freudian psychoanalysis still had a strong presence in psychological thinking, when the triune brain model was strongly influencing how people thought about brains in the animal kingdom, and when scientists were starting to get giddy imagining how much easier computers were going to make everything.My favorite parts of the book were:1) Sagan is manically impressed with terrible computer programs that try to do clinical psychology. He proceeds to copy a script from one of these interactions between a "patient" and a computer to show how awesome the program is. It is not.2) Sagan relays a "dad joke" from one of Roger Sperry's parties. The idea that a stupid joke of mine at a colleagues party could some day go down in history tickles me to death.I would definitely NOT recommend this as a popular science book because a lot of the things he describes have lost support by subsequent experiments. It would be unwise to try to use the "facts" or models presented in this book to form your opinions about nature and society.I would recommend this book as reading in a History of Psychology class. It's quick, entertaining, and interesting from a historical perspective.

Along with Jared Diamond’s The Third Chimpanzee, the Dragons of Eden has helped me understand our species. Carl Sagan is an excellent teacher and writer in that he conveys his ideas as simply as possible without academic arrogance or jargon. This book is truly accessible to nontechnical readers like myself. In a nutshell, the book talks about how our universe started, how life started and how homo sapiens came to be. It then talks about evolution, natural selection, language, neuroscience, and artificial intelligence. This book was published in 1977 so it is curious to note how far human knowledge have improved specifically in the field of neuroscience and computing. As far as I know, there are no neuroscience theories shared by Sagan in this book that has been disproved by scientists today. Neuroscience today has added more evidence to what Sagan shares in this book like how the left/right hemisphere affect the opposite sides of the human body, how corpus callosum acts as a conduit for left/right hemisphere, how are reptilian brain affects the decisions of the neurocortex, and many more. It is also breathtaking how computing has exponentially progressed today. Sagan talks about games like Hangman, Pong, and Space Wars, how computer graphics has improved, how computers could be useful if bought by mass consumers. Today, we have phones that would let us play Call of Duty with excellent graphics, a far cry from Hangman. We can learn anything online via the internet. Personal computer are cheap that everyone can afford it. Computing has indeed come a long way since the time of this book’s writing. To conclude the book, Carl Sagan warns readers of pseudoscience like astrology that will derail the progress made by science. We need more physicists, mathematicians, chemists, that will help us understand the universe.

Another remarkable book by the esteemed Carl Sagan. It is a book about human intelligence and how it emerged here on planet Earth, it is a story about us and how we came to be. Sagan uses the fields of anthropology, evolutionary biology, psychology, and computer science to give a perspective and highly interesting insight into why we can and do think. The book examines our past and our reluctance to change, Sagan writes, "In general, human societies are not innovative. They are hierarchical and ritualistic. Suggestions for change are greeted with suspicion: they imply an unpleasant future variation in ritual and hierarchy: an exchange of one set of rituals for another, or perhaps for a less structured society with fewer rituals. And yet there are times when societies must change.” So change we must but where are we going and it is not without trepidation as, "once intelligent beings achieve technology and the capacity for self-destruction of their species, the selective advantage of intelligence becomes more uncertain.” So we live in a world full of peril much of it of our own reckless doing but the future we must face, "the price we pay for the anticipation of our future is anxiety about it.” That said, as your read this book you have the wise Carl Sagan as your guide who himself although has passed on into the cosmos his words live on. “And reading itself is an amazing activity: You glance at a thin, flat object made from a tree...and the voice of the author begins to speak inside your head. (Hello!)” A fine addition to the Sagan bibliography!

This is just a hard book for me to review. Carl Sagan is brilliant, and I was interested in this book because it falls under the umbrella of biological sciences and away from Carl Sagan's focal umbrella. Yes, I read the whole thing in his voice which made it that much more enjoyable. There were moments where you could see what we would probably consider now thinly veiled racism implicit in even what we would have considered the more enlightened areas of academia (psychology, anthropology, human biology, and neuroscience, etc). Ideologies and views that we know now are wrong and even though considered the anathema to racism was in reality just a condescending nod to the slightly less superior "but still equal" "others". I have to admit even though Sagan wrote it in the arena where these ideas were considered factual, that he didn't push back a little and question them. I understand I have the benefit of hindsight in this viewpoint, and again, he wasn't discussing topics he was an expert in, but dabbling in the playing field of others and having a good time feeding his intellectual curiosities in mostly their findings. It was great to read him playing like that. The book is so clearly written in the late '70s; it's fascinating to see where we are now in relation to the exciting new technology of Pong and Space War he discusses late in the book. Often we're far off his mark, but there were a few predictions he made that were right on the button ("We may be able to engineer genes before we are able to engineer brains" as an example).Sagan can not fail for me.

An interesting read on the evolution of the brain into a set of cooperating and competing regions: the R-complex, limbic system, and the left and right hemispheres of the neocortex. The basic idea is that the deeper into the brain you go, the more ancient the functions supported. For instance, at the low level of the R-complex, the "reptilian brain" supports "dinosaur-ancient" functions like aggression, territoriality, and establishing social hierarchy. This lower region seems to both cooperate and compete with the other regions in the sense that during the day, these reptilian functions are partially repressed by the neocortex, but during dreams, it seems that the some of neocortical functions are repressed in favor of the R-complex. This is coupled with the supposition that reptiles don't seem to dream or have REM sleep. Sagan speculates that life for many animals may be experientially similar to how we humans experience dreams. Overall fun, but as it is from 1977, much of the scientific research rehashes things I encountered in school, and has progressed since then. I can see how this book influenced other books I have read, such as Techgnosis by Erik Davis and The Singularity Is Near by Ray Kurzweil.

This book is really great. I had read it when it came out back in the 1977 or in the 80s and 90s I would have been blown away and be made an acolyte of Carl Sagan. The book is that good. Sadly it was published in 1977, 40 (YES! 40!) years ago, proving some of Sagan's assumptions wrong and making the book miss a huge lot of more recent findings. This is by no means Sagan's own fault, the book feels really up to date regardless of its age, more importantly, it gives a sense of understanding to the human brain.The whole book is about the human brain and its evolution, if you're anything like me and you like science you might know a bit of neuroscience, however lately a lot of the "we're not sure" have been thrown around for every new finding. Sagan gives a feeling of "we're quite sure it's this way" or at least "I think it's this way", which is somewhat reassuring.Don't let the age of the book dissuade you off reading it though, it's a remarkably comprehensive guide to the findings and theories of the human brain's functionality and evolution, many of the theories proposed are still valid. Great book overall.

This book is fascinating more because of its author than its contents. In it, Carl Sagan talks about books as ways to hear long-dead people speak. Reading anything by The Sagan is always a treat.This book tries to be about the origin of human intelligence but it feels very, very dated today. If you want to learn about neurology and consciousness, read any book by Daniel Dennett. If you want to learn about evolutionary biology and the brain read anything by Richard Dawkins. This book tries really hard but, I'm sorry to say, fails to deliver on either of these topics.Sagan presents his own pet theories and speculative extrapolations from the preliminary science of his time. For example, he talks a lot about left vs. right brain in a way that is today understood as unscientific.There are a lot of biblical and mythological references in the book, which make it *sound* like a philosophy text, but it's rather thin on actual (sophisticated) philosophy.So I highly recommend this book for anyone who wants to listen to the words of Carl Sagan. They're beautiful and poetic words. Personally, I found it difficult to enjoy for the lack of substantive science.

"And after we returned to the savannahs and abandoned the trees, did we long for those great graceful leaps and ecstatic moments of weightlessness in the shafts of sunlight of the forest roof? Is the startle reflex of human infants today to prevent falling from the treetops?""One of the earliest consequences of the anticipatory skills that accompanied the evolution of the prefrontal lobes must have been the awareness of death. Man is probably the only organism on Earth with a relatively clear view of the inevitability of his own end.""The raising of the right hand as a symbol of greeting among humans has precisely the same significance: 'I could attack you with a weapon but choose not to wield one'".The chapter where he goes into detail on the linguistic research done with chimpanzees....whoa. I'm interested to catch up on more recent research now....."Could the pervasive dreams and common fears of 'monsters', which children develop shortly after they are able to talk, be evolutionary vestiges of quite adaptive--baboonlike-- responses to dragons[reptiles] and owls?"

Excellent book! Educational and fun, beautifully written, it ranges over many topics to offer a wide scenic tour of what a mind is, how did the human mind get to its present state, and how its future evolution might be.Packed with data, it's not your average science book, in that Sagan proffers almost more questions than answers. The tagline is very appropriate indeed, for it's more about describing and then speculating and wondering about how things are than any actual explanation of any single theory. Popular science at its best.Accidentally, it also shows how fast science progresses. By the time this book was written, the most likely hypothesis for the extinction of dinosaurs (spoiler alert) was the radiation from a nearby supernova. Something so widely known today wasn't even hinted at just forty years ago! Impressive! (PS - disclaimer: don't you worry, the remaining 99.9% of the book has aged rather well!)

Fascinating exploration of the phenomenon of intelligence - mostly human intelligence, although one of the chapters has a convincing argument that primates and animals such as dolphins have sufficient capacity to warrant the same legal protections as humans. It is, of course, an evolutionary argument, and one which Sagan applies to all the hominins (as much as he can, at least, for physical evidence is hardly exhaustive in some cases). The complex interaction of biology and environment has had a profound effect on our ability to think, and in consequence our bodies have developed some very strange characteristics. For instance, the left-hand/right-hand sides of the brain and how they process sensory information is delightfully weird, and the experiments and case studies which Sagan uses to help explain the science behind the history of the brain made the book clear and accessible.

While this was originally published over 40 years ago, it's still an enjoyable and through-provoking read. His warning about intellectual carelessness being rampant in Western society is still true today, and perhaps more insidious than ever. Sagan ventures into many different fields in this book including evolutionary biology, neuroscience, cosmology, and computer science. I personally love these mixture of topics and he handles them masterfully. If you're willing to be patient with the fact that these sciences have advanced greatly since his time, there's still much to learn from The Dragons of Eden. His articulation of the fact that the written word has the amazing ability to implant the author's voice inside the viewers mind is just one of the many deep thoughts he shares in this book. It was a pleasure to have his voice come to life in my mind, even if only for a short time.

A very insightful read. Carl Sagan tries to talk about intelligence from different perspectives. He starts with the evolutionary point of view and ends with aliens. talking about everything that makes us human in between, he even interweaves literary references relevant to each chapter in the beginning.Some of the parts of the book that come to mind is when he mentioned that predators tend to dream a lot while prey tend to do the opposite, another point was the quote by Einstein "the most incomprehensible thing about the world is that it is so comprehensible" which illustrates our large capacity for understanding complex concepts and simplifying them, maybe through analogy ON TO ANALOGY BOOKS

This is a very unique and personal tale by Carl Sagan. Here he integrates every concept of evolution and compares biological forms, since the early microbial organism to computers nowadays. The intelligence the most important feature what probably difference the human from the other species, even so, many others with the same or equivalent amount of intelligence here on earth and we don't know maybe also out in the universe. This book leads us to ask our selves about how much we understand the ways the human brain works, and how have been evolved thanks to the way of life we develop, the challenges and the paradigms of society.

4.5/5 stars. (The -0.5 is for being “out of date” on computer technologies and neuroscience.)It’s hard to find nonfiction books that are decades old that I would consider a “classic” or must-read, but Carl Sagan manages to pull it off. Like any great scientist, Sagan demonstrates the balance between logic & creativity, which is exactly what evolution has provided us.As a human, it’s important to know our own history, recent and distant evolutionary past. The more I learn about evolution, the more I realize its intersectionality with politics, economics, sociology, psychology. And therefore, it must be learn by ALL humans regardless of belief.

We are in 1977, Sagan is guessing about the development of human intelligence. He is thrilled that our big brains are speeding up development otherwise done by painstakingly slow natural selection. Remembering us that creativity and problem-solving are our unique skills. I am writing this in 2018 (more than 50 years later) and there are dozen of books out there discussing the human brain. But Sagan is still very entertaining and original. For example, for him consciousness and intelligence are result of "mere" matter sufficiently complexly arranged (his own words). Therefore, there is nothing stopping us from building intelligent machines. Just our own intelligence!

Even though brain anatomy and neuroscience are subjects far, if not unrelated, from Sagan's primary astronomical pursue, the book continuously provides fresh insights into the components of the human brain and our interconnected relations with other living species.The book started off at a rather mechanical tone but as soon as the words began to drill in, one begins to delight in this beautiful work of Sagan.Once again, a highly recommended read for the big fans of Sagan (like myself) and those who are simply interested in gaining knowledge on how far we have come in terms of our brains and our intellectual standings.

Sagan is an incredibly talented story teller. My only hesitation on this was that some of his speculations are dated and have been disproven. I would like to see this book with an updated appendix or footnotes where Sagan's theories have sinse been updated. From a cultural perspective, Sagan's views are very much products of his time. On a more scientific note, the sections on the interworkings of the brain are fascinating. My only worry is that they're dated. There are better texts for those looking for evolutionary biology or futurology. I wish Sagan were still alive and producing today.

4.5 A title that served as a precursor to many succeeding works on human and computer intelligence, Dragons of Eden takes a deeper look into the origins and development of the human brain over time, comparing its differences to the reptilian and mammalian brain which we come from. Regardless of your background or depth of expertise at neurology, psychology, or cognitive science, Carl Sagan paves the way to an evolutionary and longitudinal understanding of the human brain that any intelligence seeking reader will come to appreciate.**This title was also the recipient of the 1978 Pulitzer Prize for General Nonfiction

This was a reread for me during the covid-19 pandemic. Actually it was more like a skimming of the book. When I first read Dragons of Eden in the late 70s I found the book compelling and brilliant. Certainly for the time it was and Carl Sagan was a master at getting common folk to warm to science. Through extensive research involving not only current (for 1977) day science but also mythology and Biblical studies, Dr. Sagan presented his ideas on the evolution of the human brain. Some of his thoughts have held up well, others not so much. The book is still worth a second read because it is always time well spent when you spend it with Carl Sagan.

Sagan was notoriously too optimistic and wishfully positive about human nature. Yet very harsh things sometimes get short mentions of slipped into his writing, including his view of life outside the technological age. Thus, in Dragons, he mentions whaling in a quick couple of words without dwelling on it. At more length, in his discussion of left handedness he tells us that without toilet paper, everyone who lived in all of preindustrial history and even "in many parts of the world today" have had to wipe their bums with their hands. Seriously, would you choose to do that or to leave it unwiped like animals have to? I know which is more hygienic, and it ain't carting a foul left hand around with you !!!It was an example of him taking a too stuck up harsh attitude in order to make us love space age society by a rather insulting message of "how lucky you are, yah boo think of your ancestors". Sagan was actually wrong about this, your common sense will be relieved to know. Archaeology has found many traces of leaves or mosses being used. If you visit Doune castle in Scotland, the audio by Terry Jones will tell you all about the use of old strips of cloth or clumps of plants as toilet paper. So, unless living in a desert with neither cloth nor plants available to them, nobody has ever needed to do it with their hands.While that is my second biggest gripe with Dragons, worse is how he dismisses mind-brain dualism in one half-sentence of the introduction without giving support or "shred of evidence" for his arbitrary claim that there is no evidence for it so he may as well ignore it. Reading on beyond there he has your acceptance that you are reading the thoughts of a rigidly doctrinaire brain materialist who believed mind exists only as a function of matter, you are not reading any case or argument to help you decide whether you agree with that. (Which I don't.) Still, obviously you can read around that. Despite it, he still gives a good detailed picture, at a layman accessible level, of the brain's layered structure, of its evolution of higher powers in new layers on top of the old ones, and of how the reptile inner brain might be a generator of instincts to aggressive and irrationally destructive behaviours. What he, and his favourite psychologist Maclean who he got the idea from, call the "R-complex", he turns into a simple target for the blame for everything bad in human nature. All our problems making society work he says come from the evolutionary war of reptile versus mammal being built into our own brains: our reptile brains are the dragons within us, the flaw built in from the beginning of our evolution, hence the Dragons of Eden. He hoped progress will win the day by us deciding we like the primate brain's intelligent behaviours best and by following that path we will make our primate brains (cerebral cortices) dominate over our reptile brains.You have to agree which brain's set of behaviours are better, if you are an intelligent science reader, but it stretches hope too far to imagine that every yobbo will make this choice. Curiously as he was such a hardened atheist and the book ends with a sweeping attack on the paranormal made with scant support, this whole idea about the primate brain is a path to future betterment offered rather like a religious path, a self-contemplating self-reforming one like Buddhism.Very poetic and dreamy writing when he contemplates human brain evolution, that makes for a feel good read. "Tales of Dim Eden" - wow what an incredible chapter title. But the too many mentions of "lesions" all through the book have a feel bad effect, as he never tells us lesions are not as painful as they sound, and he seems too eager on the science to realise he is being yukky. He relies on these lesions, it just means a bit or brain being damaged or cut off from the rest, for concluding where various brain functions must be located. btw he is wrong where he says we can't use words or language in dreams. Obviously he found that in his own dreams, but it is not the case for my dreams nor for other folks I have spoken to. He was trying to theorise that dreams are the reptile brain's cosncious life. How then do they contain intelligent concepts that only the primate brain, which he says is switched off during sleep, should be able to understand?His description of the experiment of teaching deaf sign language to chimpanzees also seems quite selectively pulled to fit into his own point of view. He only gives the side that is sympathetic to the chimps, he obviously wants to feel good about his evolutionary cousins and all the brain similarities he can find. Yes it is a good thought provoker to contemplate that chimps should not be kept in effectively jail cells in scientific institutions. But he only describes how close to human the chimps in the language experiments were able to get during their manageable periods, obviously earlier in their lives, when their trainers could relate to them with some physical equality. No mention at all in Dragons of how strong fully-grown chimps get and the danger of violence. Chimps can do terrible injuries, and that has ruined attempts to have them living together with humans.You have to take the book as a push for his own unusual biological political theory about reptile and primate brains, which is a challenge to thought and has some insights but we may also decide to retain some doubts. Remember he always approved of scepticism.

Carl Sagan is a boss! This book is 40 years old and some of his predictions on the future discoveries of the human brain and technology were spot on. This is my first Carl Sagan book and I loved it. He has an ability to take very complicated scientific concepts and ideas and explain them in a non-scientific manner. In particular the past of the book when he takes the cosmic calendar and fits it into a human year to show when certain events occurred or when human milestones were reached is AMAZING!This is a must read.

Very good and informative book––as to be expected from all of Sagan's work. Although I thought he would dive into the mythology of reptiles in our cultures a little more than it did, I enjoyed how it presented neurology and the evolution of the human mind. From the slow accretion of the R-Complex to the Lymbic system to our modern-era Neocortex, we follow the growing mental capacity of Sapiens through the millions, if not billions, of years. Really fascinating information on the links and differences between the left and right hemispheres.

This book is classic Sagan. Informed speculation. Sagan is a master of weaving science with the human experience and where this book excels is when he ties scientific discovery to human myth. However, like many works of science, it shows its age. His view of psychology, especially Mental illness, is a dated view. There's mulch else that is presented that has been surpassed. But that doesn't change worth of the work. Sagan's enterprising passion of humanity and life drips from the book. And its worth it for that alone.

Although I really enjoyed the book, I did feel it rambled in parts a little bit. Nevertheless other parts were thrilling, especially the experiments with chimpanzees, wild speculations about Eden, Adam & Eve, & the almost universal myth of a dragon-like creature. The ending paragraph was my favourite & I think sums up the philosophy of the book really well- '"We are a scientific civilisation," declared Jacob Bronowski. "That means a civilisation in which knowledge & its integrity are crucial. Science is only a Latin word for knowledge...Knowledge is our destiny."'

Apart from Carl Sagan's scientific expertise, he never shies away from incorporating his philosophical 'musings' within his scholarly analysis. As opposed to various 'celebrity scientists' who focus primarily on popularity, Carl Sagan deploys his knowledge in astronomy so as to address deep-rooted questions surrounding the nature of being and purpose of human existence. His venture into uniting philosophy and science is a daunting albeit fascinating one and this book of his is definitely worth reading so as to delve into these acutely intricate notions.

This book was first published in the 1970's, so I fully expected that much of the information would be out-dated, and indeed it is. Especially the information about computer processing and DNA. That aside, there were a lot of interesting tidbits in this book. As someone who has read Dawkins--and other modern evolutionary biologists--I was stunned by Sagan's respectful references to Biblical texts. This is something that is NEVER seen in current books about evolution. It was refreshing.

I don't think it's fair to rate this book because it serves too well as a valuable snapshot of a very particular point in our scientific and philosophical development (whether right or wrong). The contents seem outdated or assumed today, but I was still completely captured by its framing of a context in which it was written. Definitely worth reading, if only to see how appropriate Sagan's thought experiments would become well after his own time.

The first time I came across the concept of three kinds of brain.. reptilian, mammalian (cortex) and neo-cortex- a concept that explains so much about what it means to be human.. seemingly rational beings built on foundations of irrational impulses. This a view of mind that I find most elegant and so far there is nothing I have read that contradicts the basic essence of this book. Carl Sagan- you gem!

A great read- Although I had partially read the book a few years ago, I picked it up two weeks ago and finished it yesterday. Carl Sagan, a master in scientific narrative, weaves a story that makes us want to venture with him to understand the origins of humanity. We are left to ponder how human intelligence got its start. However, Sagan offers many roads to travel with him on that quest to what may be called -- the Holy of Holies, the origins of life and consciousness.

Probably one of my favorite books. I'm not well-versed on any kind of biological concepts but I think Sagan does an excellent job of conveying these topics to laymen like me. It's well-written and has bits of dry humor interspersed; I can really see his personality in this novel. I would highly recommend as food for thought when considering where we've come from as a species and what really makes us tick.

Even though many suppositions or "new" findings in this book would now be considered obsolete, it is still instructive and enjoyable to read a work like this: a summary of everything we knew, in 1977, about how human intelligence came to exist. Sagan writes nimbly, and his examples are far-ranging and memorable.

This is a fascinating read on the subject of the development of human intelligence and how our species evolved morals, etc. The book is a very good summary of information packaged for the layman but with deep and thought-provoking insights that could serve to stimulate the thinking of experts in the field. Sagan's style is very humorous and engaging.

This book was published in 1977 so some of the topics touched upon are a bit outdated, especially the chapter about computers (Sagan mentions Pong, for example, as something innovative at the time). Most of the book deals with his conjectures on the evolution of the development of the human brain. It was fascinating to read about how the brain works in all its intricate details.

More like 2.5.There was a lot of good information in the book, but a remarkable proportion of the text was the author’s speculation. In addition to a lot of the assumptions and speculations (some of which were interesting, some were just kind of wild), a lot of the info was old and has now either been disproven or become knowledge that I’ve already learned, sometimes in more depth.

Very interesting. Can’t say I’d recommend this to just anyone. I enjoyed parts of it but how much I retain or am able to apply to my life is anyone’s guess. I’m still not sure if there was a point other than at the end where he makes the case to continue our intellectual and scientific growth as a society.

Considering this book was published in 1977, it remains as an inspiration. There are two points we must be aware of, first is how the definition of intelligence derives into the modern way of brain optimisation; second is Sagan's notes on psychology and sociology, which many have been experiencing great change in their milieus, which is hardly useful for valid criticism.

Sagan explains how the human brain evolved over time, how each section interacts with the others, and other ideas of how the brain functions…and doesn’t function. An interesting read and worth the $2 I spent to read Carl Sagan’s description of Pong!

4.25* ....Despite being written over 40yrs ago I found much of the content as relatable today, as I assume it was then. It is also interesting and entertaining to judge Sagan's many hypotheses for our future, that we find ourselves currently residing in now.

I really enjoyed this book. However, it is a science book written in the late 70's. Some (a lot) of the things he is speculating about have been solved or new theories have emerged. That being said, many of his predictions are eerily close to home... (my home is in the year 2017).

This books explains the evolution of our brains and why we think the way we do. A few chapter were a bit dry and I started to lose interest a couple of times. This book still gets my recommendation due to the uniqueness and insightfulness of the content discussed.👍🏻

The book's synthesis of science and myth to explain the evolution of human intelligence is as gripping as any thriller and reads like a fantasy novel, only it's real. Sagan showed that science can be poetic and elegant, and not boring in the least.

A concise look at the progress of the human mind over the millennia. Some aspects are pretty dated, but Carl Sagan's fun to read because I too am obsessed with aliens and will drop them into unrelated conversation.

Although decades old, this investigation into the human brain is a revelation. Thoroughly fascinating for someone like me who knows little about the subject. Written for the common reader and leaving us with a taste for more.

An excellent book as an overview on main science issues, specially those regarding to the raise of human condition. But as the author says, is a biology book written by a phisicist, so, don't expect fine detail on each topic.

Don’t get me wrong.... I love Carl Sagan. The beginning was slow and super factually stuffed, but I learned a lot about evolution and our place among the many other species in terms of neuroscience and behavioral science in general.

A book filled with insights on the emergence of biology's most fascinating creation - the human mind. Sagan has a way of weaving cutting edge concepts with accessible phrasing and metaphors so that the book has something to offer all types of backgrounds.

While the science is a bit dated, Sagan had the ability to simplify rather complex Neuroscience into something we can all understand. It is awesome to see how his thoughts and ideas of the future of human intelligence would be connected to computers, has come to pass and continues. Great read.

Not sure how I missed this back in the day, but I had not read it so finally got to it. This is science writing for laypeople at its very best. Sagan neither dumbs it down nor is it way too complex to understand. Absolutely wonderful.

I really liked this book. I didn’t find it dry at all. It is a little dated in parts, having been published in the 70’s, but it was interesting and shows just how intelligent Carl Sagan really was. There’s good stuff here. Recommended.

This puts the human mind into perspective! I originally read this long ago, and by reading it again now I realized I owe a great debt in understanding evolution and the development of the human mind to Carl Sagan and this book.

I will never cease to appreciate Carl Sagan's curiosity and the curiosity he worked so hard to nurture in others. This man was a true inspiring star.This book asks many deep questions. Including fascinating insights on the evolution of the human brain 🧠

"ifs" and "maybes" and theory crafting put the book more in to fiction and imagination field instead in the Science department.It is a good read for anyone who wants to just check how things may work.

This is my second read of this wonderful book on the evolution of human intelligence. While there are dyed sections it is still enlightening. Sagan is able to relate complex scientific concepts to the everyday person. I learned so much about my own evolution, and the intelligence of some animals.
Another great read from Sagan.
Dated but interesting view of computer advancement of knowledge of science.
You'll be stunned to know what a marvelous piece of equipment you are carrying on your neck. One of the best books I have read, ever.
Very information heavy, Big fan of Sagan's writing and it was interesting to get his views on "the future" at the time of writing, hence, present day.
Carl's speculations are fun at times, but way outside the reach of his expertise. On top of that, Brain science has changed at lot in the last 40 years leaving this book woefully out of date.

The Dragons of Eden by Carl Sagan explores the humanity’s evolution in light of the broader history of the Earth and the universe. Written in Sagan’s iconic style, a mix of the poetic and academic, the book displays a few novel approaches to understanding our world. In particular, Sagan introduces the “Cosmic Calendar,” which encapsulates all the time of the cosmos into a single calendar year. In this framing, humanity’s time on earth only appears in the last hour of the last day. It really puts into perspective our place in the broader universe. Sagan would visualize this thought device in his legendary television series, “Cosmos.” I was also struck by Sagan’s willingness to explore our relationship with potential life outside of Earth. It’s no surprise that Sagan won the Pulitzer Prize for this work, as it is a classic of science communication. It’s still an engaging and worthy read after nearly 45 years since its publication.

The dragons of the Eden-Carl Sagan- I was expecting a book about mythology, but I discovered a study about evolutionary biology/psychology. There is obviously a link between those, but the mythological aspect is not emphasized well enough. The most interesting idea of the book is the one of the triune brain, a theory which claims that the brain has three parts: the R-complex-the primitive part, the limbic brain-where our emotions reside and the neocortex-the rational side. According to this theory, humans have evolved from using the most lower side to the most advanced part that operates intelligently. Another intriguing aspect of it is the fact that those parts of the brain are shared with animals, from the most primitive ones to the most developed ones. The R-complex is also called the reptilian brain because reptiles also have it, while the limbic brain is shared with the mammals. The R-complex the center of fear, survival and basic needs. Metaphorically, it could be said that those two complementary and opposite forces that reside in the human consciousness-love/lust and death/destruction/violence, Eros and Thantos, whom Freud claims that they the two instincts of the human psyche, are practically triggered by the reptilian brain, also known as the R-complex. It's the archaic consciousness that can be observed at those primitive civilizations or tribes : magical thinking, superstitions, fear of the unknown, tribal mentality, the need of survival. What should be noted here is that ancient civilizations worshiped serpents and this cult can be found all over the world. This could be an interesting metaphor of the existence of the lower level of consciousnesses. Let's not forget that violence(human sacrifices to the gods, for example) and sex(orgies) were highly regarded in those ancient cultures. The story of the Bible- the fall of man- could be taken as an allegory of the falling to the lowest level of consciousness. Adam and Eve could me personifications of the limbic brain and the neocortex(the gray matter), while the serpent is obviously the R-complex. The knowledge of good and evil is the black and white mentality of humans that attempt to divide everything in two, according to their limited perceptions. As a side note, I'd like to mention that mental illness such as psychosis could be triggered be an over-activation of the R-complex- which is somewhat plausible considering the fact that there are similarities between people from the tribes and those who are mentally ill. Apparently, the tribesmen could be considered schizotypal. Furthermore, could the apparition of those saviors considered gods be taken as a metaphor for evolving and dominating the lower level of consciousness. A classic example is Christianity, where the never-ending battle between the serpent- which symbolizes fear, and Christ- the symbol of love, the antithetical feeling, is obvious. To conclude, I'd like to point out another well-known theories that are analogical with the one of the triune brain. It's the Jungian idea of the thee levels of consciousness: the unconscious, the subconscious and the conscious- and the Freudian idea of the thee parts of the personality:id, ego and super-ego- which can be linked to the three parts of the brain.

The eponymous dragons are our primeval adversaries, the reptilian kimonos that stalked the steaming jungles of "dim Eden" long long ago. They are our biological progenitors. In their cold, reptilian gaze, we discern something of our most primitive selves. Sagan imbues the word, in fact, with all sorts of eerie meanings. The "reptilian" portions of our brain and psyche bear the stamp of what Darwin might have called our lowly origin. We still retain the reptilian segment of our brain, as Sagan shows--though millions of years of evolution have significantly complicated and expanded the neural structures that reptiles left our proto-mammalian ancestors some 200 million years ago. The word ("reptilian") comes to acquire a special, if peculiarly derisive, meaning. It refers to those primitive characteristics we like to think have been thoroughly extirpated, but that lurk, unbudgingly, in the innermost cortex of our brains. Sagan re-examines the foundational myths of Western culture (the Garden of Eden, in particular) through the lens of an evolutionary biologist and anthropologist, wondering why these stories continue to speak so powerfully to us. In Eve's encounter with the serpent, he finds something deeply stirring; man's strangely reflexive encounter with his distant relative from the past.The best moments are those when Sagan delivers on what his title promises: "speculations on the evolution of human intelligence." Many of these speculations were impressively canny & inspired. Many are gorgeously written:"Human intelligence is fundamentally indebted to the millions of years our ancestors spent aloft in the trees. And after we returned on the savannas and abandoned the trees, did we long for those great graceful leaps and ecstatic movements of weightlessness in the shafts of sunlight on the forest roof? Is the startle reflex of human infants today to prevent falling from the trees? Are our nighttime dreams of flying and our daytime passion for flight ... nostalgic reminiscences of those days gone by in the branches in the high forest?"I enjoyed Sagan's startling speculations, yet I wish Dragons would've spent more time fleshing them out. There's too much general information and not enough of the "speculations on human intelligence" that he promised in his title. By the final two books, he seems to have abandoned this project altogether, launching into a full-scale argument on the political implications of human intelligence; the last chapter speculates about extra-terrestrial intelligence. There's lots of interesting stuff here, but the ideas are somewhat scattered, and the lack of focus inhibited Sagan from developing a more coherent and compelling thesis.

If you don’t read any other book by the late great Carl Sagan, read “The Dragons of Eden: Speculations of the Evolution of Human Intelligence” (Ballantine Books; 1977.) Although first published in 1977 most of the information is still up to date. It’s still the most readable and enjoyable book of “pop science” on the market. It probably was the biggest reason why Carl Sagan got the go-ahead for the award-winning “Cosmos” television series of 1980.The genesis of this book was from a lecture Sagan presented the very first Jacob Bronowski Memorial Lecture in 1975 held at the University of Toronto. Bronowski, like Sagan, also had a popular science-based television series called “The Ascent of Man” which aired on the BBC in 1973. Sagan, already a published author, got the nod to expand the lecture and this book was the result. What Makes This Book Special?Although lauded for his work in NASA and in making science cool, Sagan’s greatest gift was his ability to teach. Sagan was able to take a wide variety of sciences and synthesize them together to make an understandable narrative. This book touches on computer programming, art, biology, cosmology, anthropology, mythology and psychology. From all of these various sources comes one answer to the question, “How did we get here?”The book isn’t just large blocks of text but is broken up by charts, black and white photos and illustrations. Each chapter begins with a pertinent quote or two from such sources of wisdom as Aristotle, William Shakespeare, John Milton, Sigmund Freud and Lewis Carroll. It gives the book a nice continuity, as if the questions Sagan touches on in the book have been the same questions pondered all of our species’ existence.Who Won’t Like It?“The Dragons of Eden” will upset those who believe in God, Creationism and dragons. Sagan goes on to prove that none of those three ever existed except in our own imaginations. Those readers whose minds are already firmly made up about God, Creationism or dragons will probably not be swayed by Sagan’s logical and humorous approach.The title of the book is taken from a quote from the book of Job in the Bible: “I am a brother to dragons and a companion to owls.” Using a Bible quote may be seen as offensive by some religious people.

It is a brilliant book, that - I believe - can stand the challenge of time even in this field.
