Most of these resonate nicely with my own thoughts, and - although no novelty - help me better phrase my own ideas.The reptilian R-complex and the Limbic system, the new Neocortex with its Frontal lobe (STAND, MAN, STAND!!!) and the team work of the two hemispheres (the rational, logical left and the innovative, pattern seeking artsy right) - these things we could have found in a manual. But Sagan's own reflections on population control and his assessment of the present day's "state of affairs", his appeal to use our Neocortex (i.e. the reason) and his thirst (his hope) that the existence of other intelligent civilizations could demonstrate that it is possible for societies to live and prosper with advanced technology (the mathematical "existence theorem") - these insights are of most value.His open mind towards computers comes coupled with an invitation to continue to let our innovative brain work (i.e. the story of the Chinese translation machine "out of sight, out of mind" ==> "Invisible idiot" ... he he).His clear identification of our aggressivity as coming from the reptilian R-complex, his appraisal "As a consequence of social and technological changes of the last few centuries, the World is not working well" and many other examples in the book speak about a honest person, a professional who tries his best to present a balanced, candid picture.

This book is an interesting look into the evolution of the brain, extensive exploration into how it works or at least might work including comparisons to the brains and intelligence of other species, how that evolution shaped behaviour and societies, and a look into the future of the development of human intelligence. Given that it was written in 1977, some of the science is likely dated (I don't know enough about it to say), but a lot of Sagan's commentary is based on studies that had been conducted at the time, many very recently as of its writing. While our understanding of the brain and of conditions affecting it have almost certainly gotten better in the intervening years, that commentary is still interesting to read, and I imagine that some if not most of the science still holds up today. Where the book really shows its age is in a section about where human intelligence will take us, where he discusses what at the time was modern computer science and even early electronic games. Obviously, we have the benefit of knowing where those things went, but it's still interesting to read his speculations and enthusiasm about them. On the other hand, there are other things discussed in this section that are still relevant today, such as decisions about when to use science and when not to and how society decides what things are objectionable, even delving into the difficult discussion of what stage of development a human is a human in relation to the topic of abortion, an argument which still carries on to this day. There are certainly more recent books to read if you're looking for information about brain science, but this one is still an interesting read if you want to hear about Sagan's perspective and opinions on the topic. This book was somewhat of an experiment for him and he admits as much, given that his primary expertise is astrophysics, but I think it succeeds in provoking thought nonetheless even today.

A list of my interests are as follows: Carl Sagan, Dragons, Eden, Evolution, Human Intelligence. This seemed to have it all.After some entry-level neuroanatomy, we got right into the evolution, primatology, religious metaphor, even dinosaurs. Dinosaurs! How'd you work that in? I don't know. I don't care. Awesome.The casting out of Eden was analogized by the sudden expansion in the Homo braincase, which makes us the only animals who have painful births, as God promised we would after we snapped up that good knowledge apple. There's a poetry to the bigger cranium/Tree of Knowledge punishment mirror that the Bible writers couldn't possibly have been aware of. The dragon aspect was our primeval enemy, the gott-damnt reptiles. When they were dinosaurs we were creepy little voles, and they roamed in the day eating each other and us when they could find us. We crawled out at night and ate their eggs. Nowadays, all we have in terms of giant reptiles are komodo dragons, who are dying out. So we basically won. I also liked the bit about how the universal primate fears no matter how far up or down the evolutionary chain we go are heights, snakes, and darkness. Genetically transmitted terrors. Reptiles are such bastards that they got into the top three, next to falling out of trees (which is a big deal considering for much of our phylogenetic history, we lived in trees) and darkness, where murder lives. A good chunk of this book seemed like common knowledge, especially with how enamored I am of evolutionary theory, but there were little tidbits and confirmations that I feel more comfortable having received from Carl Sagan himself. He's also a fantastic writer, clear and concise without being pedantic, and not above throwing in the occasional dick joke. My kinda dude. If you can't work a dick joke in, what you're talking about isn't real science.R.I.P, High Prince of Wry Science. I'm sure you're screaming up at us right now. But, you know. Approvingly.

Carl Sagan is one of the most accomplished writers of his time and i picked up the book with a lot of expectations. This is a book about the evolution of human brain which takes us on a journey of our development from our ancestors. The book dresses various issues namely the development of our brain from those of worms, fishes, reptile, mammals to eventually its present state. Taking this hypothesis forward it goes on to explain the inherent R-complex (reptilian complex) and the triune brain that resides in the depths of our brain. These and the un-human behaviour arising due to them is what is referred to as the "chained dragons in the dungeons of our mind". The relation between these aspects and our basic aversion to reptiles, the dreams of falling through empty space are all speculated upon in a lucidly simple yet scientific manner. A whole host of other issues such as the typical functions of the left and right halves of the brain, the "future" development of artificial intelligence, the sleep patterns and their evolution over time, extraterrestrial life forms etc are discussed for the curious reader. Though ahead of its time, I found it difficult to appreciate this work fully coming as it did straight after a thorough reading of Norman Doidge's "The Brain that Changes Itself". As it happens quite a few of Sagan's hypothesis have been eschewed over time including "localisation" in the brain and the forms that alien life may or may not take. Also, at times the mumbo jumbo becomes a bit too much and the train of thought is lost from one chapter to another. A good book but certainly not a great one (not by modern standards atleast) , but still worth a read due to the range of topics it covers.

With The Dragons of Eden, Carl Sagan ventures off his usual themes by writing a book about cognitive science and how it relates to human evolution. This made me a bit uneasy because I have limited knowledge about neuroscience and cognition which means I have to take everything Sagan says at face value. I don't mind doing that because Sagan is a genius, but usually, I prefer to be knowledgeable about the subjects I read. At times, the arguments were technical and slowed down my reading, but other times they were enlightening and enjoyable. There were many times throughout the book where I would pause and go "wow, amazing", or something to that effect. In fact, this book is jam packed with interesting facts and even more interesting speculations about early humans and the future of the brain. This alone makes the book a worthy read. However, it goes downhill towards the later chapters. Since it was written in 1977, the computer chapter was dated (i.e. Pong was cutting edge), but I still got the idea Sagan was trying to convey even if it wasn't a fun chapter to read. Also, it was written with the theme of the Garden of Eden and Sagan ties in a few metaphors and anecdotes to his arguments relating to the Genesis myth. I didn't find these particularly interesting but it didn't detract too much from the reading. Finally, the illustrations in the book were of good quality but there were too many footnotes to compete with image captions. The combination of image captions, footnotes, and technical jargon created a distracting reading experience. Overall, a good book.

Sagan acknowledges at the end that "To write a book on subject so far from one's primary training is at best incautious." and it's true that a book subtitled "Speculations on the Future of Human Intelligence" might be unexpected coming from an astronomer. But Sagan was knowledgeable about science in general, which made him more qualified than most to engage in this discussion of how the mind has developed and how it works. These speculations were written in '77, so there's certainly been further work on many of the areas mentioned. Some ideas, such as "This surely means there is a part of the brain which remembers sounds and images, but not thoughts." (p. 80) seem likely to be true in some sense, and others, such as "We may be able to engineer genes before we are able to engineer brains." (p. 213) have proven to be absolutely correct.Sagan gets surprisingly (to me at least) philosophical for someone with a reputation as a hard scientist. After telling the story of rocketry pioneer Robert Goddard's inspiration for developing space vehicles, he asks "Can it be an accident that this vision of voyages to the planets ... was glimpsed in the limbs of a tree?" (p. 81) Well, yes, actually!There are some other points where his insights go a bit far - for example, the speculations on the origin of the correspondence between left/right and bad/good I think make some unwarranted leaps of etymology.But overall this is an informative and entertaining book by a master of scientific thinking and communication. Well worth picking up, even almost 40 years after it was written.

The original lecture, which Carl Sagan then elaborated into Dragons of Eden: Speculations on the Evolution of Human Intelligence, must have been wild. Despite biology lying a few meters out of Sagan's typical lane, he applies his keen analysis, rigor, and dry wit admirably to a big problem: what on earth is human intelligence? Sagan constructs detailed pictures of partitions of the brain, the interplay of language and intelligence, and some amusingly outdated descriptions of computers and the future of computing's role in our lives (and I'll hand it to Sagan -- his prediction of computing's future ubiquity proved correct).However, there is no getting around that nagging word in the title of the book, 'speculations.' Sagan's prose is so charmingly didactic, you walk away from his book feeling energized and educated. So it's disappointing to read a beloved educator propose a question and give the written version of a shrug as an answer; too many parts felt like My Dinner with Andre masquerading as science. But Sagan doesn't hide the speculative nature of the work, and I think it is a testament to Sagan's rational mind that many conjectures the book makes have largely survived over the decades, or at least aren't complete bunkum. So I would not say that anything in this book is paradigm shattering; a good deal of its insights, such as its centerpiece hypothesis of a triune brain, are old hat by now. But as a starting point for investigating the brain and its fascinating interactions with our evolution as a species, it does its job well. At worse, you get to go on a journey that Sagan was very clearly enthusiastic about.

There is something so marvelous about following the trajectory of how we humans have come to understand ourselves, and this has become another milestone in understanding its own subject in an even higher meta-narrative than that self-acknowledged in the book. Eminently readable and thought-provoking, even though I know scientific inquiry and theory have moved much further since 1977, and that much of this is outdated. Outdated as it is, much of this contains things I had never thought about, and I'm looking forward to following up on in terms of how much further we have advanced -- but from what I do know, the dominant theories of evolution and the chapters on paleontology and primatology are not immensely changed. I imagine the biggest revisions of what is written here would come from studies of the functioning of the brain, of which I know almost nothing. The coolest thing I think? That this was written when there were 200,000 digital computers in existence; that it seriously discusses the educational possibilities of pong; the distance we have come with computers, and how many dreams of the 70s were fulfilled and how many still lie in the future. Perhaps the most exciting are all of the things that have come to pass that could never have been imagined 40 years ago. It's like evolution in action. Now we are talking about how computers and the use of social media seem themselves to be rewiring the brain -- something you would have predicted from reading this. To me there can be no greater proof of lasting value.

Carl Sagan is goddamn smart, and boyishly optimistic about humanity ability to harness the power of our own intelligence for good. He makes compelling, if outdated, arguments supporting his theories. It helps that I've watched and re-watched so many old episodes of Cosmos that I can imagine Sagan's voice reading me this book.It's hard to summarize this book, because Sagan jumps around a bit. Generally, his aim is to use current science to elucidate the evolutionary underpinnings of human intelligence and to speculate about how human intelligence will interact with technology and alien lifeforms in the future. What I most enjoyed was his clear joy and optimism about current technology. Here he is describing the latest video game:A perfectly elastic ball bouncing between two surfaces. Each player is given a dial that permits him to intercept the ball with a movable "racket"... The game is very interesting. There is a clear learning experience involved which depends exclusively on Newton's second for linear motion.Yup, Carl Sagan is describing Pong like it's a powerful learning tool, and he's being genuine. I think that sums up the book for me. Sagan is so smart that he can distill complicated ideas into their scientific fundamentals. The rest of us mortals see a screen with a ball flying back and forth; he sees Newton's second law. We see the world filled with people, and problems, and quotidian life; he sees the interaction of neural circuits, brain hemispheres, and the evolution of behavior patterns over millennia.

For me, University was a time of intellectual awakening. In the first two years this was not so much from lectures and interminable pracs that I attended. Rather it was from the realisation of how much art and science and technology I had never come across before. In first year university we were required to study a non-science subject; I enrolled in Psychology. In amongst developing our paper plane skills, lectures on Skinner, perception, personality, emotion, were lectures on human consciousness and intelligence - subjects that I continue to find fascinating. Spurred on by these lectures I bought and read a profound, influential, new release by Carl Sagan: The Dragons of Eden.It is hard to convey how influential this book was for me. I still to this day have not read a science book so fascinatingly and simply written on such an easily misconstrued subject as the evolution of human intelligence. It was only when writing this review that I became aware that The Dragons of Eden was awarded the 1978 Pulitzer prize. Forty years on and ‘Evolution’, like ‘climate change’ have become the bête noire subjects of the conservative right of western democratic politics. As for ‘intelligence’, the self-help book-shelves have become replete with trite nonsense on how to define, measure, and improve your and your team’s ‘intelligence’. I recommend a small dose of Sagan-sense to them all.Read the complete review here: http://dragonlaughing.tumblr.com/post...

I haven't come across any scientific writer as engaging as Carl Sagan. In a subject usually considered too banal and objective for the average person to be interested in, Carl has a knack for explaining complex ideas and concepts in a simple, easy-to-read prose. I thank him entirely for sparking my interest in science and setting me on an improved path of scepticism and critical thinking. Where was the Carl Sagan references in high school science classes? This was the third book of his I've read, after Pale Blue Dot and The Demon Haunted World. I would say this one was the most subjective of them all. He states at the beginning of the book that a lot of the ideas have little evidence or support among the vast majority of the scientific community (not in those exact words), yet I found his hypothesis' compelling and plausible in almost every case. One of these ideas proposed the notion that throughout history, humans have systematically eradicated all other primates that showed signs of intelligence, i.e Neanderthals and Hominids. This has become more prominent today with the forced inclosure of chimps around the world. I'm not going to do the book much justice if I try and rattle off all of the things that Carl explained so eloquently throughout, but he's such and amazing writer I just feel the need to spread the word! Essential reading in my eyes, Carl will surgically pick your brain apart and leave you with a better understanding of your inner workings. A lot of concepts can be hard to grasp, but the ones that aren't make it all worth while.

One of the lesser points Sagan introduces is the analytical check our "left" brain must impose on our "right" brain's more intuitive connections. Ironically I would argue that Sagan's hesitance to check himself was this book's biggest failure. Often he excitedly drew out connections, usually preceded by a phrase such as "I wonder," that do not stand his left-brained test of reason. With that said, I found the book worth the read. Sagan draws up a quick tour of human evolutionary lineage with a focus on our neocortical developments. He also always had a ready comparison to primates in order to morefully showcase what makes us "human". As always, the line is thinner and more vague than many more orthodox religions would like to believe. One major takeaway was the human ability, through the development of the neocortex, to have built-in "intelligence", I.e. analytical thinking, as compared to "instinct". Whereas instinctual information is programmed into tightly packed DNA (and is therefore limited in nature) and survives solely off adaptive selection, intelligence (or extragenetic info) resides in a larger brain capacity.. it is the ability to think on the fly and respond successfully to innumerable changing environments and situations. Sagan introduces many other varying ideas and usually does a good job supporting them scientifically. All in all, if you ignore anything he says about aliens or computers, it's a good read.

A delight to anybody who has a working neocortex. Carl has this gift to wind up theories and arguments to an extent where you seem to loose sight of the pretext on which the plot was built and suddenly he unravels the knot letting the beads of the joy fall to the feet of endless speculation and science. The books opens up by rating the human species on account of their intelligence and letting us know that we have come far but it was a ride very close to an abyss. Most of the fellow travelers had the ammunition to make it but only we persisted, we won. We should not let this journey from the savannas of Africa to being the dominant species on the planet, end up into nothingness. The book spectacularly dissects the human brain, human dreams, our humane possible interaction with chimps and a shows us a future with possibilities only limited by the limitlessness of our intelligence. I personally liked the arguments put up on the reasoning of human dreams-their meanings, their past, their purpose. Carl never believed in foretelling the future but incidentally he himself predicted the rise of computation to an amazing degree of accuracy. Accounting for the fact that in 1977, computers were limited to labs with loaded grants and high walled corporations, he accurately described the roles of computers in each human's life. I was thrilled to read this part as it gives me scale to measure the soothsaying capability of my hero.The book is strongly recommended to everyone.

This book had been sitting on my bookshelf back at home, beckoning to me, for many decades. After listening to about three different podcasts going on about how great Carl Sagan in (yes, he is a Dude) and then finding this book (along with The Odyssey) at that Mumbai bookshop I could not resist. Also read during my long sea voyage I intersperced the chapters of this book with the audio book of Dawkins' Greatest Show On Earth (which I'd read and reviewed in paper form earlier). Since it came out in 1977 I basically discounted everything written in it as 'out-of-date', but it still came up with some interesting ideas. Basically the premise of the book is how our neo-cortex, the 'human' part of our brains, competes with the R-cortex, the reptillian part evolved hundreds of millions of years ago. There are some excellent anecodotes and factoids here but I found the book lacked a real focus or narrative - although maybe that's a result of my comparison of it with Dawkins' books. I'm a big fan of Sagan's ideas and it's written very well and was pretty enjoyable so I certainly can't critisise it too much - maybe my expectations were just set too high. I swapped this book, along with The Odyssey, with White Tiger and a book on Seneca left on the cargo ship by two disembarking cycle tourists.

This is the firs book I read from Carl Sagan, he certainly had a beautiful mind. I expected to read about hominids and how they started to use tools, and working in groups to gather food or hunt, instead Sagan spills his thoughts and knowledge about the human brain, things like the processing of language in the brain, the use of hemispheres, the development of abilities in the brain, even primates using sign language, and brain deceases. He then talks about machine intelligence (computers), and the possibility of evolved intelligent beings from distant galaxies.I'm always compelled when I read books from decades ago about scientific development, including discoveries, knowledge and technology. I read about a scientific breakthrough in a popular newspaper only to find out someone has been doing research or has proposed such possibilities decades ago, and to think that clever minds like Sagan have already pondered on these ideas a long time before.Sagan's tone is very friendly, it is a pleasure to find friendliness in science, but just as he was in his television shows he really enjoys wondering and traveling within his mind in the greatness of science, and he invites you to come along with him.PS. There a few amusing reference about marihuana, referring to the experiences of a user as an "informant".

Reading Dragons of Eden is like having a conversation with the most intelligent person you've met as your friend meticulously explains how a vast array of sciences and art add up to his theory on life on earth, human intelligence, and the search for extraterrestrial life. I enjoyed every moment of it. Of course I learned a lot - did you know, for example, that by comparing the anatomy of our brains to, say, the brains of a lizard, we can surmise what a lizard thinks about? Did you also know that falling and snakes are the only two innate fears in a moneky, regardless of whether the monkey has ever been exposed to the dangers of either? But the best part was the logic of it all. Sagan has an ability to pull from his vast repository of knowledge and to ponder theories and possibilities as casually as someone might theorize over a drink. Except he's Carl Sagan and far more likely to be correct.Dragons of Eden was written in 1977, so many of his theories have since been expanded. I found his chapter theorizing that the next stage in human intelligence would involve symbiosis with the cimputer especially adorable. The final chapter, explaining how and why we would be able to communicate with extraterrestrials, should we find them, was absolutely brilliant and still poignant today.I recommend this book to anyone with a curious mind.

"Dragons of Eden" is of course way outdated (1977) and more speculative than scientific, but it is a very charming, amusing and thought-inspiring book which I've thoroughly enjoyed reading. Framed within the Big History of the Universe converted to 1 year to illustrate the relative time scales, it presents a bunch of fascinating subjects very well:- brain anatomy, the mind's conflicting operative systems, and the evolution of intelligence- prehistory with mammals and "dragons" (dinosaurs)- dreams and why we sleep- prehistoric suppression and (probably) eradication of other humanoids by humans, and the ethics of modern human society's continued imprisonment and exploitation of apes for scientific research- potential bases of mental illnesses- anthropocentrism (which Sagan is very much guilty of himself btw)- speculations about the future of humanity linked to space exploration and the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (of course... as usual). - there is also a comically outdated chapter about computersI don't necessarily agree with Sagan's opinions or conclusions, and I don't expect the science to be entirely (or even mostly) correct, but Sagan has a knack for explaining complex subjects so that they are both easily comprehensible and fascinating, and help shed light on the complex evolutionary plot of Life and humanity. A lovely read.

An insightful, thought-provoking book on the themes of evolution and intelligence. Honestly, I often felt the Eden metaphor was pushing it: sure, the connection between the pains of childbirth punishment and our increased brain size, as well as toiling the fields and our move from hunter/gatherer to farmer are clever and you get the feeling that you're uncovering a mystery as you read it, but the snake's connection to the dinosaurs, and metaphors of other religions - that felt more like reading an exercise in grasping at straws. I didn't realise as I was reading this how long ago it had been written. It was only when I got to the last chapter concerning Sagan's musings on the future of technology and computer sciences, and read his amused response at this newfangled games 'Pong' and 'Hangman' that can now be played on the computer, that I realised how old these musings were. It was interesting how accurate Sagan's predictions of the miniturisation of computers were, but there is still a long way to go, I'm sure, before the more shocking of his predictions come into maturation (which I'm quite convinced they will). The most commendable aspect of this book is perhaps its readability. Some of the theories he explains are very complicated, but instead of skimming over them, he wrote both eloquently and coherently, and that's a skill I think more scientists should practise.

A little outdated, but a nice read. I have found Sagan to be truly one of the most insightful authors, and this book is no exception. Is less relevant and hits less heavy than his other works (Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors, Demon-Haunted World, Cosmos). Unfortunately many of the main ideas espoused have fallen out of scientific favor--mainly the triune brain and warring hemispheres theories. Sagan the populizer is caught oversimplifying the complex structure of the brain; perhaps to appeal to a more general audience, or perhaps because it is not his area of expertise. The section on computer interface was especially dull, considering how much scientific progress was achieved in the past couple of decades.I took special interest in the idea that as predatory mammals dream, they allow their "R-complex" to take control, in an environment where it can do no harm. This means that reptiles perception of reality could be very similar to our dream state (i.e. reptiles are literally "livin' the dream"). The idea posited of Eden as an extended metaphor for human evolution is also very intriguing.The takeaway message "knowledge is our destiny" seems tacked on. The book is worth reading, but it doesn't build as well as Sagan's other works.

I had certainly heard of Carl Sagan, but only in terms of cosmology. I had no idea that he wrote extensively on the field of evolutionary biology-stimulated by his wife, the biologist Ann Druyan. My field is not science, so The Dragon's of Eden was my first encounter with the idea of the tripartite brain. The idea does not originate with Sagan, as he himself points out, but this slender volume makes the idea quite assessable for the lay person and, more importantly, it creatively explores the idea's possible implications. Although I read this book years ago, I have thought of it several times a week since then, as I speculate upon some of the biological causes of human behavior. Newer models of the brain have already proved some of the basic ideas in this book as a bit oversimplified, but if you are looking for an introduction to speculating about how the brain's evolution may shape human behaviors, this is great place to start. I found the book a "mind blower"-and I always pick it up used when I see it to give to friends. Prepare to have your perception of perception itself turned upside down.

It was interesting to read a book by Carl Sagan that deals with the brain and intelligence. I enjoyed it, but sometimes had difficulty picturing the processes of the left and right hemispheres of the brain. In other writings dealing with the brain (articles, text books) I see things like "The language component of our brain resides in the left hemisphere for most of us." Then there is a bit of acknowledgement given to the rare few (like me) whose language component resides in the other hemisphere. This book gives no acknowledgement to those with reversed hemispheres. Of course, this is not a major flaw, but I still see it as a bit of a flaw.When reading about the various parts of the brain and their functions, it is normal to imagine such things taking place in oneself. I had to make a very conscious effort while reading to note that I must picture the left hemisphere when the right is mentioned and vice versa. In summary, it is a good read and very interesting. The challenge I faced will not apply to many people. Nevertheless, it would've been nice if he acknowledged that some of us exist with reversed hemispheres.

This was certainly not what I expected. Carl Sagan is primarily known for his television series Cosmos and his work in astronomy. So when I discovered that he wrote a book about the evolution of human intelligence I was intrigued. The fact I found a three dollar paperback copy at a used book store sealed the deal. Carl Sagan definitely managed to wow me again. The technical chapters about the construct and storage capacity of the brain was really fascinating. Also the last two chapters which speculate on the future of human intelligence is truly mind boggling. The book was published in the 70's and many of his predictions about the roles that digital computers would play in our lives have already come true. He is also unabashedly excited about the educational potential of computing resources, something that scarcely crosses my mind today but will from now on. The tail end of last sentence of the book, a quote from Jacob Bronowski, really hit it home for me. "...knowledge is our destiny."I've been trying not to give Carl Sagan 5 stars but I just can't do it. This book is too good and you should read it.

This book was written in 1977, so much of what Sagan writes about may be dated. This, however, does not matter. Despite any inaccuracies, this book is informative, but this is not what makes it a remarkable, Pulitzer prize winning work. Sagan is more than a really smart person. Along with clearly explaining complex things about the human brain, Sagan gives his own speculations and theories. Whether he is commenting on the future of human civilization or the relationship dreams and dragons, Sagan presents his theories in a manner that is hard to argue against. Because so much of the book is empirically based, Sagan gives himself a basis to make his claims. On top of this, Sagan himself admits that much of what he is saying is purely speculation, and should not be taken at face value. This in turn gives him a sense of modesty that is easy relate to. Throughout the book, Sagan references great thinkers like Plato and Aristotle, showing the utmost respect for them. I think years from now, Sagan may be regarded just as highly as Plato and Aristotle. He is a brilliant individual who presents ideas that are thought provoking and plausible.

I cannot praise this book enough for its level of quality scientific information. Carl Sagan has not only put a remarkable effort into writing a book that is not within the realm of his own subject, but also delivers the information in such an effortlessly smooth writing style, that is not easy when dealing with dry scientific data. To top it, he has sprinkled the content with delightful tongue-in-cheek humor. The book presents forth, using the available evidence in several related fields like evolutionary biology, genetics & zoology amongst others, a powerful and intelligent theory on the evolution of the human brain and intelligence. Carl Sagan talks about the "Triune Structure" of the brain which took form because of subsequent accrual of various parts of the brain along the lines of evolution of till humans appeared. The discussion on specific functions of the components of Triune brain is is quite an eye opening experience. A richly informative piece that gives you new perspective on the social rituals & practices and will make you view them in a new light! A must read for everyone!

I was a fan of Sagan's before reading Dragons of Eden -- but somehow had not picked up one of his books. I knew him through his series Cosmos, which captured in my late teenage self the bulk of the wonder I felt about science, a feeling that has persisted into my career in medicine.That voice of Sagan's program, the sense of wonder, comes through perfectly in this title. I did not find much to expand my understanding of the subject here -- but this has, more or less, been my field of study all my adult life. The predominant explanations of the late 70s, when this was written, are in some cases no longer predominant. However, I was surprised at the prescience of some of Dr. Sagan's conjectures. While his fascination with Moore's "law" is kind of quaint (especially his amazement at a processor with a few thousand transistors), his extrapolation of brain-machine-interface work was just about dead on. In fact, one of his examples, of a closed-loop control of epileptic seizures, has only recently been brought to market, some 35 years later. That's pretty remarkable.Having dipped in, I certainly plan the read the rest of his major works in the near future.

What I really like about this book is that it is so easily understandable. Sagan is a talented teacher; he has a talent for transmitting knowledge... The way the book was written is simple, but the matters addressed are not. Evolution, the evolution of brain, intelligence...this is something I always found interesting. I don't have some great background knowledge about it, yet there was not anything that I have not understood in the book. (or so I felt)What I liked most was the question of intelligence in animals. That for me is one of the most fascinating themes. I something feel people invent definitions just to exclude animals from things we call "human". Who can claim animals don't have language when chimps are capable of using sing language? Nevertheless, in every linguistic book you'll find: “Language is a solely human accomplishment...." I don't think it is and I don't like how humans think they are masters of the world. In fact it is possible that some other creature (monkeys, dolphins for example) will evolve and we will disappear.

Difficult to rate, because the science described has moved on so rapidly since 1977, the publication date. I read it in order to feel re-acquainted with Sagan's friendly tone in his effort to popularize science ( live a few blocks from the old KCET studios from the "Cosmos" era). In that regard, it is very ingenious and concise. And frankly, the underlying scientific concepts still need popularizing. Appreciation of genetic science, paleontology, and even psychiatry is now extremely low - "pop culture" has eclipsed science and introspection for too many of the decades since the '70s - so Sagan's hopeful tone evokes nostalgia now. He aspired to be a polymath as well as a popularizer, so at the time of publication, I remember that he was knocked down for straying away from astronomy. But he asked good questions here, and not all of his answers are outdated. He responds to Julian Jaynes, in a fashion. He warns against pseudo-science, which has only proliferated and put national policy at risk, since. Glad to have picked it up!

Dragons of Eden is a nonfiction book that takes the reader from the beginnings of man all the way up to modern days. He expresses his theories about evolution in a way that can be easily comprehended with some focus. Sagan discusses reasons for human behavior and how these behavior might have been beneficial to earlier man during the prehistoric ages. For example, our fear of heights. In Sagan’s opinion, humans are inherently afraid of heights because early humans swung from tree to tree like apes. The easiest way to die (at this time) was by falling to the jungle floor. Sagan also goes into detail about parallels between the Bible and human evolution. This part was most intriguing to me, as a Catholic, and I gained new insight into evolutionary concepts. Overall, the book was quite effective in establishing Sagan’s ideas. He used lots of concrete evidence and understandable language. I think that anyone with a basic understanding and interest in science or anthropology would enjoy this book.

Read this Sagan study of evolution back in the 80sFrom Wikipedia:Sagan discusses the search for a quantitative means of measuring intelligence. He argues that the brain to body mass ratio is an extremely good correlative indicator for intelligence, with humans having the highest ratio and dolphins the second highest, though he views the trend as breaking down at smaller scales, with some small animals (ants in particular) placing disproportionately high on the list. Other topics mentioned include the evolution of the brain (with emphasis on the function of the neocortex in humans), the evolutionary purpose of sleep and dreams, demonstration of sign language abilities by chimps and the purpose of mankind's innate fears and myths. The title "The Dragons of Eden" is borrowed from the notion that man's early struggle for survival in the face of predators, and in particular a fear of reptiles, may have led to cultural beliefs and myths about dragons.The Dragons of Eden won a Pulitzer Prize. In 2002, John Skoyles and Dorion Sagan published a followup entitled Up from Dragons.

Extraordinarily well written, this book covers the extent of history according to modern science, with an emphasis on the principles of evolution and the progression of man-like species. The subtitle betrays that a lot of the work is speculative, but this is not to say that it is far-fetched. Sagan's ideas are always based upon factual data and are admirable if only for the fact that they are honest and informed attempts. For example, Sagan talks about how animals such as monkeys have specific calls to warn each other of specific threats, and offers up the suggestion that the hissing of reptiles is perhaps the reason behind 'shh' as the universal sound for 'quiet' among humans because it is a remnant instinctual rememberance of warnings against our early competitors. Obviously this is not a fact, but it is interesting and promotes thought. The entire book is amusing and stimulates independent thought outside of the general subject matter. Highly recommended.

Obviously, being a scientific text from thirty-three years ago, it's not a surprise that some of the business in this book is outdated. The last chapter, which is ostensibly about the future evolution of the human brain, could very well be called "Grandpa is afraid of abortions and the computers". That being said, I really appreciate the straight forward and engaging way in which Sagan writes about such difficult material. His use of language is friendly and readable, his examples often personal, clever, and easy to connect to.Despite the earlier mention of Sagan's unease about technology, he's extremely open to animal equality, careful to make the distinctions that one species' intelligence or suffering can't be a measure of another's. Which only serves to make the "Hey! Pong! Neat!" moments that much funnier. The "calendar" and "timeline" of human mental evolution in the opening section of the book were partcularly interesting and easy to understand.

Everyone read this book now. If a fifteen-year-old can plow through it and understand the major part, so can you.To quote what I wrote about it for my library's summer reading program:"The book discusses the evolution of the human brain and connects that evolution to physiology, myth, animal potential, dreams and computer. Further, it declares science as the path to improving life."The connections drawn to myth are reminiscent of this article in the Endicott Studio archives. Scientific explanations for myth are as a rule awesome.Also, the book is funny:"a human being has about a hundred times more bits of information in his brain than a rabbit does. I do not know that it means very much to say that a human being is a hundred times smarter than a rabbit, but I am not certain that it is a ridiculous contention. (It does not, of course, follow that a hundred rabbits are as smart as one human being.)" - p. 48

I really miss Carl Sagan. More than anyone else, he ignited and cultivated my enduring interest in science. This book won the Pulitzer Prize for non-fiction back in 1977, the year I graduated from high school. I had not even heard of Carl Sagan at that time. It wasn't until his Cosmos series came out on PBS in the early 80's that he became a force in my life. So, now, 36 years after it was published I finally read this important book which is simply Dr. Sagan's educated speculations about the evolutionary history and future of the human mind. Most of what he writes about is very interesting and revealing about human nature. Much, however, is very dated. I kind of got a kick out of his descriptions of several amazing state of the art (for 1977) computer programs -- one of them being the video game Pong!A very thoughtful and thought-provoking book, but I wish I had read it when it had first been published.

I was a big Carl Sagan fan when I was a kid and read and own every book he has ever written. The only snoozer was Comet. This book was an excellent read, although the theory of recapitulation has been discredited. Carl Sagan’s books, including “Cosmos”, drove me towards the scientific method and a rejection of rationalism or mysticism. I was an agnostic from 1982 to 1989 as a result. Another good book is Sagan’s The Demon Haunted World. It was his last book before he died and I think he was trying to find a bridge between empiricism and mysticism. One of the most moving of his work for me is when he described going into the NY Public Library and marking the number of books he could read if he read one a week for the rest of his life. It was a pitiful small amount compared to the rest of the library and since I read that, I committed to only reading the best of literature. I began reading classics and text books exclusively. No more Sci-Fi or Lowie L’Amour books.

1. It feels like non-fiction got a lot better since then at exploiting the curiosity gaps.2. We learned a lot about neuroscience since 1977, but still moved in the same direction, so the book is still correct about many things at large, although details are often important.3. Contrary to Geoffrey Miller, who tells that evolutionary psychology was extremely controversial at the moment (just two years after the Sociobiology release—which, by the way, is not mentioned at all), here’s a Pulitzer winner that has a lot about how the human mind was defined by its evolution (although, admittedly, without many crucial details).4. A good book to learn something about the history of the area. If you want to learn about evolutionary psychology itself, you’d be better off starting elsewhere.

The second to last chapter on machine intelligence is a little dated (it was written in 1977), however the preceding 7 chapters offer interesting insights into the nature of biological intelligence, our contingent evolutionary history, and a few intriguing speculations on the deep past. A couple of these speculations (such as the notion that our legends of goblins, trolls, giants, and gnomes might be genetic memories of our ancestors battling Australopithecus) border on the ridiculous. Sagan was fond of the reefer; perhaps this line was inspired under its influence. It's easy to tell from the prose that this book was written before Cosmos or Pale Blue Dot. Feels a little more casual and loose with 'out there' ideas that he is in later works Despite these misgivings, it was a short and enjoyable read.

Like any science book written almost 30 years ago, a great deal of the information in The Dragons of Eden is outdated. This holds especially true for The Dragons of Eden, as it largely concerns itself with neuroscience. Neuroscience has seen explosive growth and revision in the last 15 years.However, if you keep that in mind, I think that this can still be a very enjoyable read. Sagan writes in a very engaging way. His scientific imagination, his curiosity, his earnest hypothesizing and his ability to weave together information from almost every sphere of the humanities and sciences is incredible. This book is also illuminating for anyone interested in the history of science. It serves as a well developed "snapshot" of thinking in the 1970s.Sagan fans and dilettantes are sure to enjoy this book, but don't expect it to bring you up to date in the field.

Although im not one for a history lesson on the evolution of man, there is no way i, or anyone else, can resist to hear about the humbling and controversial story that Sagan depicts, because he is so captivating in his work that he actually draws you in to a point where it becomes a one sided conversation. Its almost as if you are given the unimaginable opportunity to sit down and listen to this incredible mind just shoot out theories, ideas, beliefs, and the straight up truth of how we came to be. Starting at a time when mankind was maybe just a twinkle of an idea of a star, Sagan goes over the ongoing debate of how we cam to be. Spreading to early man to almost present day( for the book anyway) Sagan creates a timeline in your head that leaves nothing to chance, and everything happens for a reason.

Never have I read anything on the subject of human intelligence as fascinating and as charming - Isaac Asimov. Oh, I concur vehemently. Throughout my life's curiosity about all the things science, I have heard great things about this physicist/humanitarian. Never have I stumbled upon his work till this gem of a book and boy what I have stumbled upon is so pure and breathtaking. Sagan presents and dissects idea with such clarity and interesting way you fall in love with science/nature and cosmos the way you never felt before. He is such a great teacher and student of sciences, the what-ifs he puts forth are truly out of the box and enlightens one. Throughout reading this tour de force my mind was creating what-ifs of its own. While reading the book I felt immense pleasure and pride to have belonged to a species that gave rise to such an ingenious spirit that is CARL SAGAN.

An interesting read even if a bit dated. The book goes from reptilian and aviary brains to mammalian, non-human primate, then human brains, showing which parts are shared and which are exclusive to humans. A good introduction to the various parts and corresponding functions of the brain. Particularly interesting were the stories of chimpanzees conversing with humans via computer terminals and the effects of certain brain injuries. Less interesting was the wild speculation on the author's part on why primates have an innate fear of snakes, why humans eat eggs for breakfast, and the unfulfilled hope of artificial intelligence.

this book is exceptional. and inspite of mildly heavy scientific terminology, is a definite page turner. one reason, I believe, is the fact that it is about our brain, the most complex thing on earth, and the most fascinating thing in today's society. and the origins of our nervous system is told in a fascinating story, giving alongside a hint of how natural selection works, and why men is what men is, why we basically act hasty and irrational, why we are angry most of the time(kind of survival mechanism of early chimpanzee-man carried to us), why we sleep and dream while sleeping, and why most of the man see dreams of falling, sometimes even in half-sleep state. this book is exceptional, two times over.

I feel bad giving this book two stars because I enjoyed reading it (and can see why it won a Pulitzer back in '77) but because most of the science behind his ideas on the evolution of intelligence is now considered incorrect (the triune brain, huge chunks of Freud) the book itself didn't hold up to time very well, although it was an admirable effort for sure. However, as a fun old-kitschy-psych-book it was quite entertaining, whenever Sagan says "I sometimes wonder.." you know something funny or ridiculous is coming next. Some of the research talked about in the book is still relevant and I found the parts concerning chimps using sign language to be fascinating. Turns out if you teach a chimp the sign for "dirty" he will start using it as an insult, as in "you dirty monkey".

Another boon (read book, this inadvertent typo, seems appropriate) on evolution - with the twist of being related to the characteristic topics of Carl Sagan, ET intelligence.He dwells on everything mentioned in the title: intelligence, evolution, humans, and also on emotions, culture, language - how they developed and how they are related.What it means to be human, and how human are other (non-human) animals.The major brain divisions and their functions and evolution - it's a good read for anyone interested in science in general and evolutionary biology in particular; I take it a small treat for my interests in psychology also - how do we explain some of our reactions, individual and societal.Oh, he almost predicted "Planet of the Apes" :)

I've read this book during my senior year in the university and because my Cytogenetics professor required us to do so. If you're not into science you probably would have ignore reading this book, but it really does not matter because this book was orgasmic; blissful in just a short course of reading, informative and promising, beautiful and eventually very surprising. Every trajectory of detail will pull your brains and exhibit your R-complex like it did million years ago. Yes, it is so depressing to think Sagan is not with us here anymore, but at least he is happy now and in solitude with his billions and billions of stars and lovely planets. A favorite.

Being 30-some odd years behind the times, I recently finished reading The Dragons of Eden which was written by the famous author and scientist, Carl Sagan, and was originally published in 1977. As the full title attests, the topic is the evolutionary development of the human brain. As is to be expected, the technological references in the book are hopelessly dated, and I can safely assume that the scientific information is dated as well. I would have been very interested in a new edition with updated information, but unfortunately, Sagan died in 1996. Perhaps I will find a newer book on the topic of human intelligence.

The book was published in the 1970s, so the sections on computing and SETI are a bit long in the tooth, and I think we've learned a bit more about our biochemistry since the book was written, but the book as a whole is nonetheless definitely worth reading. The ideas are definitely not out of date. The book is well put together and thought-provoking. Sagan is a skeptic in the philosophical sense: someone who relies on evidence and reasoning rather than revelation and faith, but he does not show an antagonistic attitude toward anyone. The book is a comfortable read, well cushioned with appropriate stories that support his reasoning and conclusions. Large bibliography and a glossary.

A bit dated in places, but I always love me some Carl Sagan. As the subtitle says the book has plenty of speculation--some on the money, some not so much (this was written in 1977 after all)--but one always knows where Carl is doing it and that he wouldn't mind tossing out a hypothesis that is not borne out by evidence. These days I always wonder how J.R.R. Tolkien or C.S. Lewis, who frequently criticized science for being "un-mythic," would take Sagan.

Definitely not a light read. It makes the book more interesting to have some background knowledge of psychology and evolution of but it is not necessary in order to understand the book because Sagan does a good job of explaining and providing definitions for most things. The beginning seemed rather tedious and I wasn't sure I could get through the book but as I adapted it became intensely interesting. Several times I found myself sitting back and breathlessly saying wow as I contemplated something I had just read. Sagan offers wonderful insight, this is a great book to expand anyone’s knowledge and make them think.

This is my first time reading Sagan's work and I must say I enjoyed it. Sagan writes very well and is very entertaining. However, this book is outdated, which is only most noticeable in the last 15-20% of the book when he discusses technology. My one concern is that the particular science that I'm not familiar with (neuroanatomy), I'm not sure how reliable it is due to the date that this book was published. Otherwise, there is still material that can be learned from this book that is highly interesting and thought-provoking. It does not take long to read nor is it hard, and still entertaining nonethless.

An intellectual and hypothesizing analysis of the evolution of the human mind. Carl Sagan has great prose but is sometimes a little too boggled down with technical terminology that his intended audience "the layman" might have some difficulty. It is an interesting read. I am more on the Gould camp (that human intelligence appeared out of chance and if you reset the cosmic clock we might not be here and our definition of intelligence might never exist) in regards to the evolution of human intelligence but I enjoyed it nonetheless. "Science is only the Latin word for knowledge...Knowledge is is our destiny."

I was a little bored initially but somewhere after the first few chapters it starts getting very intriguing. Thoroughly enjoyed reading the different case-studies/experiments he discusses in the book. Well in most of the book he can't assert anything with certainty but based on the observations made, he does hypothesize a few things about the brain. Towards the end of the book, the reader can themselves start coming up with their own hypothesis (which was the real fun part I feel). It's a small book, so I wouldn't think much before picking up this book. Go ahead and read it if you want to understand some aspects of the brain and if you enjoy reading about the human anatomy in general.

Readability 6. Rating 4. Sagan always impresses me with the vitality of his mind, but, unfortunately, that is about as far as this book impressed me. The subtitle is "speculations on the evolution of human intelligence." An accurate assessment - the book has the feel of a rumination, or collection of random musings on a topic that he stretches quite widely (e.g., he includes an extensive discussion of abortion). It lacks a coherent message, other than that the neocortex is a big deal. OK, thanks. Also, since it was written in the late 1970s, it is dated both in sociological feel as well as the state of science. Not terrible, but not wonderful like I have come to expect.

Tl;dr Carl Sagan was brilliant. Great book 10/10 would read again.He's able to communicate complex and otherwise monotonous information in a way that draws you in, like a story. His ability to link the development of human intelligence to the evolution of complex life really helped me make meaningful connections to things I already understood.He also goes into the left and right hemispheres, and individual regions, of the brain. Through this, and the comparison to other animals brains, he allows us a window into his understanding of the basic mechanics of human intelligence and consciousness.

For those of you who just came across this book recently, just a friendly note, some points of this book might be quite outdated by now. I myself read it almost 10 years ago.But as other Carl Sagan's book, this is another book that worth your time, especially if you already read and enjoyed another Carl Sagan's book before. I also found the speculations in this book to be intriguing. You could also learn a thing or two about how the human brain works in general.Another recommended nonfiction book from me to general readers. Just don't take all of it as a reference, you must filter the points you want to digest from this book.

This book is amazingly exploring the working styles of our brain, it discusses why we are thinking this way as a human, what is the difference between us and other animals and the probable steps of this transformation, the mentioned experiments are amazing especially the one that discusses brain lateralization which I found by a mere coincidence to be working, I met three or four parts where I couldn't understand where he was getting at, but bottom line it is a very interesting and mind opening book.

I loved this book! Though, after some independent research, I've learned that the triune theory of the human brain, which features heavily in the book, has since been superseded by newer models, that doesn't diminish the relevance of some of the questions Sagan raises - the development of the fetal brain in relation to the abortion debate, for example, or the association of some of our more barbaric behavior to older evolutionary instincts. It's an excellent, easy read, as is typical with Sagan books, and I highly recommend it.

this is an enjoyable and thought-provoking book, as is anything by carl sagan. however, it just doesn't age as well as some of his other books, as some of the key areas of exploration -- neurology and computing, for example -- have just come so far in the intervening years so as to render much of his speculation quaint. that's not to say there's nothing to take away from this book -- sagan's knack for brilliant insights is on full display, as is his entertaining style -- but it does put a ceiling on the heights this book can reach.

While dated and somewhat out of date, a fascinating and engaging look at the evolution of intelligence. This was a brilliant read and wonderfully written. Sagan has got a knack for wonderful writing and presenting his ideas. Like all of his books, it is biased and he is not shy about interjecting his own thoughts and opinions along with research and science based information. But coming from someone as brilliant as he is, I certainly didn't mind his take and input. I did chuckle at his marveling at the new computer game, "Pong." See? Dated.

Sagan gives a good overview of an area he is not particularly an expert of: the evolution of the brain. While being a great teacher explaining the reader some biological, psychological and evolutionary aspects of it and sharing his ideas/theories (tested or to be tested) with us, he also does what a responsible scientist would do: make an attempt to explain our bad habits and actions with this evolution and emphasize them for the readers so maybe the world will be a better place... At times the book reads a bit dull but otherwise a great book to read and learns a lot.

Dated, yes, and a bit out of his element (as he prefaces the book with) but it's still Sagan doing what he's best at: Giving sublime, awe-inspiring insights into the potential of scientific endeavors and the incredible power of the human mind and boiling it down into a simple, concise language anyone can understand. When stretched to the limits of the imagination, science becomes a thing of mystical wonder every bit as curious and exciting as the ancient myths about the behavior of the gods or the existence of dragons, and yet it all remains so intrinsically human.

It is truly amazing how Sagan is able to describe our history without mentioning any historical facts. What he does, then, is explaining it through science: the beginning of the universe (astronomy), our evolution (biology), what our brain can tell about ourselves (anatomy)... he also even mentions some aspects regarding physics (in the "artificial intelligence" section). In other words: if you are seeking a book that will not only help you understand yourself, but leave you with a plethora of knowledge due to Sagan's creativity and examples mentioned, this book is waiting for you :)

Pretty awesome and inspiring. This book was written in the 70's so it was very interesting to see where science, computers, and technology was at back than. Regardless of the era it was written in, I learned a lot for the book. It a perspective changer more than anything else, aside from maybe a tribute to the miraculousness of the human/mammalian brian. It's certainly a stand out among other Sagan book's largely due to subject matter. So read it if you can. It be proud of the brain that allows you to do so.

Hmmmmm, I guess you can say I read this, if you count the fact that is runs from page 208, than skips to the Index at page 241. I don't think the previous owner liked those pages, but on close expection the missing pages don't look like they were ripped out, it is seamless between those two places ... it is doubly shame because it's a first edition hardcover print. :( Outside that the book is great and I'd really love to read a modern equivalent. If anyone knows of one please direct me.

Another great read from the master Carl Sagan. It was a very enlightening book, going through the evolution, the brain with a little bit of psychology in the middle (which was a pleasant surprise) and the end with his thoughts about the future. Carl Sagan is known for explaining complicated things in an easy manner and this book is no exception, it flowed easily even with the specific terms he applied. I guess it helped the fact that I've got some background knowledge on the subject, even though I would recommend this book to anyone that's curious about life.

Wonderful book to understand the biological basis of the human mind. It approaches such understanding from an evolution perspective that gradually builds up into the understanding of the human mind as an achievement of nature in relation to other species. It also examines the future of mind in terms of electronic technology, but the emphasis is not on that. It also examines the specific functions of the parts of the brain and makes interesting "wondering about's" from the mind of this great scientist. Very enjoyable if you are interested in the mysteries of the human and animal brain.

I read this book for a class. And I'm truly glad I did because it was very good. The great thing about this book it's that it's not just a divulgation reading, but a text that often asks you questions while you read, and allows you to wonder about a surprising range of topics, from animal mistreat to abortion.I like to think that just by reading this book many people would question their posture in such topics, and I also find it appalling that even all those years after Sagan wrote this many debates still stand, and many postures still need changing.

Considering that have happened almost 40 years since this book was written it is very impressive the amount of 'new' information it contains. Definitively you have to praise Dr. Sagan for caring so much about give to the public the latest available knowledge.I really enjoy the symmetry that Sagan draws between the bible and the Greek myths and some important points of the human evolution, and also I like how he structures the book from the past to the present, and from our planet to the universe.Even today, 2015, I would recommend this book to anyone interested in human evolution.

I've always been a Carl Sagan fan but this is the first book of his I picked up. He writes for the layman but digs deep on the subject of the human mind and uncovers a lot on the evolution of the organ and the ways in which it has put humans above of other animals on Earth. The book is gripping throughout, always delving into new perspective and inquiry. Towards the end Sagan's clairvoyance becomes clear when he begins discussing computers and an age in which handheld computers will be commonplace...

I'll recommend this book to everyone. The book is a spectacular journey into deciphering the evolution of human intelligence. Each chapter is a another saga of wonderment and surprises as you unravel the deep mysteries and functioning of human brain, the most important part in our body. Carl Sagan is a scientific gift for the mankind, who sees the human species beyond all social distinctions as a race destined to achieve supreme intelligence. The book will help you open your mind and understand how far we have come from a single celled organism.

A fascinating book for anyone interested in the development of the human mind. Sagan endeavours to answer some of the questions about the evolution of the homo-sapien brain and it's impact upon our rise to the apex of the power pyramid. For the student of psychology, then this is a must. For the student of self-improvement or self-deification, then this is also a must. Sagan provides a wealth of data and insight into the functioning and development of the brain. The resulting book should function as a 'quick start' guide to the use of the brain.

Despite the fact that it was published decades ago, this book still rings true in most areas. Sagan presents his material clearly and without any notable bias. He makes clear distinctions between science and speculation, and does not hide the fact that many of his ideas are yet to be proved. Though the premise is pretty basic, it is a great read for any layperson interested in human intelligence and evolution, and is not only informative, but fun.

More a rambling essay covering a range of related topics than a cohesive text, this book is nonetheless enjoyable. Being more than 30 years old, some of the science is outdated, but otherwise it serves as a decent introduction to the human brain and its capabilities. Recommended follow-ups to this book: The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat and other Oliver Sacks works, and Phantoms in the Brain by V.S. Ramachandran.

As a big Sagan fan I read this more to see what he was thinking back in 1977 rather than to learn a lot about the human brain and intelligence. I would have to say that it's the my least favorite of his books. As smart as he was, I think he would have been better off leaving topics of this nature to the experts in the field of neuroscience. Still it was interesting to read *his* views on these matters.

This book gave me such a brain-crush on Carl Sagan: I dreamt I gave the man a *hug* the other night, his writing made me so happy. I've seen "Cosmos" several times so I know I love me some Sagan, but this was, amazingly, the first time I'd read anything by him. Incredible. You will probably never find anyone else who's both as excited and qualified to teach you about science. Read this book, dammit.

When I first picked up this book to read, I was concerned that it was dated (1977) and written by Carl Sagan (didn't he narrate populist space documentaries). Turns out he was an accomplished biologist, well versed in studies of "origin and the early evolution of life". He does a fine job of bringing along the reader on a journey into the depths and evolution of the human brain. Easy to follow and very informative, I was very happy to have spent my vacation reading this book.

I was so impressed by Sagan's Cosmos that I wanted to read anything else of his that I could get my hands on. I enjoyed Dragons of Eden a little less than Cosmos, mostly because we still know so little about the human brain that most of the topics discussed here contained quite a bit more speculation than those in Cosmos. Still, this book does a great job of getting the reader thinking about the origins of intelligence and where we might be going.

My ratings of books on Goodreads are solely a crude ranking of their utility to me, and not an evaluation of literary merit, entertainment value, social importance, humor, insightfulness, scientific accuracy, creative vigor, suspensefulness of plot, depth of characters, vitality of theme, excitement of climax, satisfaction of ending, or any other combination of dimensions of value which we are expected to boil down through some fabulous alchemy into a single digit.

This book is good for all, but exceptionally interesting for those studying the human brain, the function of the human mind, or the human condition in general. The stories which serve to illustrate Sagan's theories are presented exquisitely. The statistics which support Sagan's points are laid out in a logical and easy-to-understand fashion. The book is short enough to get through in one sitting. A must read. Period.

This is basically a series of essays written by the famous cosmologist around the subject of human intelligence: its evolution and posssible future improvement. It was written in the mid 1970's and much of the author's musing now seem simplistic.I think if I had read the book when it was published I would have given it a 4 star rating, but now the material is too dated.His section on what digital computers can do would be laughed at by a 6th grade child.

Read this book. First off, great disposition. Fairly short chapters which made it an easy read suitable for, in my case, lunch hours at work. Sagan tried, and in my opinion succeeded, to explain rather complex ideas in a graspable way, without, I must say, making it feel like being talked down to. Sure, in some places it's a out-dated book, but in my case I found it to be an interesting perspective on the world as it once was.

Take note of the word "speculations" in the sub-title -- this book has a generous helping of hand-waving mixed in with the references to research and analysis. I actually found that Sagan's speculations made the read more enjoyable. Just imagine that you're sitting down in a comfortable coffee shop to have an energetic "what-if" contest with a very intelligent and articulate buddy, trying to get to the bottom of why people KNOW they're people.

Carl talks quite well about how we as humans evolved. "Why we are the way we are?" is, i think the central question.The book is a well articulated account of history, science, and philosophy; all at the same time.It is interesting when he questions "human-ness" and talks about what separates us from "beasts". It shines a bright light upon the fact that we are not the only intelligent animals on earth and how we share a good part of subconscious with them.

This is the book Sagan won a Pulitzer for is also feels like his weediest tome; counted multiple reference to the smoking of trees in this one. More than anything, though, this book is reminder that, with Sagan's untimely passing in 1996, the world was deprived of quite possibly the greatest video game reviewer of the modern era. Who else, in a review of "Pong," would praise its ability to deepen a player's understanding of Newtonian physics? Uncle Carl would.

Pros: An excellent read on how the human brain may have built-up from our reptilian ancestors. Exudes a clear prose with Sagan's normal hint of pedagogy - a perfect introduction to basic human brain evolution.Cons: I can barely hold this against the book, but the information is dated (obviously). Overall: I would recommend this book to anyone interested in human evolution, especially as an introduction to human brain adaptation.

Of course any 1977 book on neurology and human evolutionary biology is going to be dated -- but this was still a interesting read. These are indeed Sagan's speculations, just as the title promises. I certainly got the sense that Sagan would've been a fascinating person to just hang around and chat with.I'd be interested to have someone as engaging on the these topics -- but also current, and knowledgeable -- bring this up to date.

Another seriously influential book for me. I bought it as a high school sophomore in the gift shop of the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History. It set me on a course that took me to Cornell (where Sagan was a faculty member, though I never met him), carried me through graduate school (I got a PhD on evolution of intelligent behavior), and now has me working at the museum where I bought the book. Not bad for a book outside his astronomical expertise.

Though some passages (on the wonders and possibilities of computers, for example) read a little dated in 2013, this book is still relevant and interesting. I like the hopeful tone the book picks up towards the end, and Sagan's musings on humanity's future and thoughtful and instructive. Also, Sagan is a great writer with an eye for concision and structure, so his ideas never overwhelm either him or the layman reader.

This is one of Sagan's earliest works, and his most award-winning. Compared to Cosmos or Broca's Brain, the writing is not as good. But the book lays out Sagan's basic scientific and moral philosophies, and explores many of the deepest themes of his life and work. The subtitle may be about human intelligence, but Sagan explores a wide range of topics that anyone would find enjoyable and fascinating.

Dragons of Eden is a book about evolution written in an engaging way. Sometimes Sagan tries to tie in myths to early evolution, but those metaphors were usually pretty weak, as he often admitted. Instead, the best parts of the book focused on how our brains developed and some conjectures as to why certain brain activities exist (like dreaming). The book definitely made me think and was pretty enjoyable.

Carl Sagan is always a fascinating yet clear writer of science. Both as an intro to studies on the human and non-human brains, and to Sagan's philosophizing on what those discoveries mean to us, the book kept me interested for the most part.On the other hand, many of the theories he muses about here are rather outdated (Recapitulation theory, much of the dream chapter), so a modern reader should read it with a grain of salt.
